description:
Rhinopithecus roxellana, commonly known as the Sichuan golden snub-nosed monkey, is a species of Old World monkey found in the mountains of central China. It is a member of the genus Rhinopithecus, which are collectively referred to as the snub-nosed monkeys.

The Sichuan golden snub-nosed monkey is characterized by its distinctive golden-brown fur, which appears to have a fluffy or woolly texture. It has a prominent upturned nose, which is the feature that gives the genus its common name. The species is adapted to the cold, high-altitude environments of the Sichuan and Shaanxi provinces, where it inhabits dense temperate coniferous and deciduous forests.

Sichuan golden snub-nosed monkeys are highly social animals, living in large multi-male, multi-female troops. They are arboreal and spend most of their time in the trees, foraging for a diet primarily composed of leaves, flowers, fruits, and lichens. These monkeys play an important ecological role in their mountain habitats, contributing to the dispersal of seeds and the regulation of plant growth.

Due to habitat loss and fragmentation, the Sichuan golden snub-nosed monkey is classified as an Endangered species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Conservation efforts, including the establishment of protected areas, are crucial for the long-term survival of this unique primate species.
